intro: Rubus argillaceus, commonly known as the clayberry or argillaceous blackberry, is a species of bramble native to the eastern United States. It is characterized by its prickly stems and compound leaves with serrated edges. The plant produces small, dark purple to black berries that are typically harvested in the fall. It thrives in moist, clay-rich soils and is often found in woodland edges and stream banks. Botanically, it belongs to the Rubiaceae family and is closely related to other brambles like Rubus species.
